title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from South Sudan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in South Sudan?
preds: In October of 2018, a large group of civilians was abducted. Without a doubt, this has the potential to escalate into a more intense situation. There have been, in the past, strategic campaigns to target civilians including policies that cause widespread starvation and forced relocation. There is a relatively high chance that this situation will escalate further in the next year and a half.

South Sudan is still incredibly dangerous for civilians, especially since the latest peace agreement between the government and rebel groups has not seemed to stopped the fighting. An estimated 383,000 people have died (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/26/world/africa/south-sudan-civil-war-deaths.html) throughout the conflict. Although there have been targeted killings of civilians on all sides and the government has given free reign for soldiers to commit atrocities (https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2018/09/south-sudan-government-troops-and-militias-given-free-rein-to-commit-new-atrocities/), there have not been large-scale systematic killings. I am giving this a 5% chance of occurring because 900 civilians were abducted in October 2018 (https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2019/country-chapters/south-sudan) and escalation is possible, but highly unlikely.

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 (also see that comment for ambiguity regarding "mass killing campaign") Other judgments:
- EWP itself estimate 18.3% [1]
- Crowd forecast here is 0%. Inside view:
- According to EWP, "South Sudan currently has ongoing state-led and non-state-led mass killings, with the state-led episode perpetrated against Neuer civilians, and the non-state-led episode perpetrated by followers of rebel leader Riek Machar against Dinka civilians." [1] These seem to capture the fault lines of the ongoing civil . war. Usually, I would have said that there aren't many ways for this to get worse, but taking a brief look at Wikipedia disabused me of that notion. [2] [3] There are possibilities for some inter- or intra-ethnic conflicts to get worse, in addition to the civil war. However, my best guess is that that is still exceedingly unlikely given the civil war. Most other conflicts did not exceed 100 casualties from what I can tell, and where likely entangled in the civil war in one way or another. Overall judgment:
- The EWP judgment seems to be off due to the fact the ongoing mass killings seem to capture most of the violence, and it's hard to see how South Sudan could get worse. It's still somewhat plausible so 0% also seems off. My best guess is 2%. [1] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/south-sudan
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Sudanese_Civil_War
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_violence_in_South_Sudan
Using my previous forecast to Jan 1st.
